SENT.plain: One cannot now predict with accuracy the degree of deficit that may be anticipated following a carotid occlusion even when the condition of the opposite artery is known
When symptoms and signs occur, they are most likely related to the hemisphere or eye on the side of the occlusion
In patients with carotid occlusion, a higher rate of severe complications and mortality was encountered following arteriography than in the general study population

Among randomized patients with a carotid occlusion and a contralateral carotid stenosis, 63% of medically treated patients were alive at the end of a 66-month follow-up, whereas only 34% of surgically treated patients were still living
Surgical mortality was extremely high in patients with a carotid occlusion
Sixty-seven percent mortality occurred in patients undergoing surgery within one week of a cerebral infarction
